title.text: Creating a rule based system for text mining of Norwegian breast cancer pathology reports

entities.text: text mining of Norwegian breast cancer pathology

abstractContent.text: National cancer registries collect cancer related information from multiple sources and make it available for research.
Part of this information originates from pathology reports, and in this pre-study the possibility of a system for automatic extraction of information from Norwegian pathology reports is investigated.

entities.text: automatic extraction of information from Norwegian pathology reports

abstractContent.text: A set of 40 pathology reports describing breast cancer tissue samples has been used to develop a rule based system for information extraction.
To validate the performance of this system its output has been compared to the data produced by experts doing manual encoding of the same pathology reports.
On average , a precision of 80%, a recall of 98% and an F-score of 86% has been achieved, showing that such a system is indeed feasible .

introductionContent.text: Cancer is a common cause for death worldwide, with about 14 million new cases each year).

In the Nordic countries it is mandatory to report each incidence of cancer to national registries and in Norway, the reported data is handled by the Cancer Registry of Norway, (Kreftregisteret i Oslo).
The registry has as its main functions to monitor the cancer prevalence in Norway by collecting data on all incidences of cancer, and also to make this data available for research).

In 2013, there were about 30,000 new cases of cancer in Norway, the most common cancer type for women being breast cancer with 3,220 new cases, and the most common type for men being prostate cancer with 4,836 new cases.
Part of the data that the Cancer Registry of Norway handles originates from pathology reports.

A pathology report is written by a pathologist examining a tissue sample from a patient with known or suspected cancer and the report contains a number of test results, measurements and descriptions of the sample.
The National Cancer Registry of Norway receives about 180,000 pathology reports each year and 25 full time expert coders transfer data from the free text reports to a database via an XML template.

The manual encoding of the pathology reports requires special knowledge for each cancer type and the transferal is a complicated and time consuming task where the coders have to read and interpret the content of each report.
There is therefore a need of a system capable of automatic information extraction.
The system should be able to accurately extract the relevant fields for each type of cancer.
